description: From Latin hyperbolē, from Ancient Greek ὑπερβολή (huperbolḗ, “excess, exaggeration”), from ὑπέρ (hupér, “above”) + βάλλω (bállō, “I throw”). Doublet of hyperbola.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, rhetoric, literature) Deliberate or unintentional overstatement, particularly extreme overstatement.
examples: The great staircase, however, may be termed, without much hyperbole, a feature of grandeur and magnificence.

entries.meaning: (countable) An instance or example of such overstatement.
examples: The honourable gentleman forces us to hear a good deal of this detestable rhetoric; and then he asks why, if the secretaries of the Nizam and the King of Oude use all these tropes and hyperboles, Lord Ellenborough should not indulge in the same sort of eloquence?
